nodes.label: Automated Bone Marrow Cytology System
nodes.summary: An end-to-end deep learning system for automated analysis of bone marrow aspirate digital whole slide images (WSIs), designed to support hematological diagnosis by automating region selection, cell detection, and classification.

nodes.label: Region of Interest (ROI) Detection
nodes.summary: The first computational step of the system, which automatically detects and selects suitable regions or tiles from a large WSI for subsequent cytological analysis.

nodes.label: Algorithm
nodes.summary: A fine-tuned DenseNet model is employed to rapidly and automatically select appropriate ROI tiles from a WSI.

nodes.label: Performance
nodes.summary: Achieved a cross-validation accuracy of 0.97, precision of 0.90, and a ROC AUC of 0.99.

nodes.label: Cell Detection and Classification
nodes.summary: The core component that simultaneously identifies individual bone marrow cells and assigns them to one of numerous discrete classes based on cytological features.

nodes.label: Algorithm
nodes.summary: Implements a YOLO (You Only Look Once) model, specifically YOLOV4, trained from scratch to perform object detection and classification in a single step.

nodes.label: YOLO Model Features
nodes.summary: Solves detection and classification simultaneously using a regression approach. YOLOV4 is optimized for small object detection and uses complete intersection-over-union (CIoU) loss for faster convergence and better accuracy.

nodes.label: Performance
nodes.summary: Achieved a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 0.75, an average F1-score of 0.78, and a Log-average miss rate of 0.31 for detecting and classifying 16 key cellular and non-cellular objects.

nodes.label: Histogram of Cell Types (HCT)
nodes.summary: A novel representation that summarizes the collective cytomorphological information for a patient by quantifying the class probability distribution of all identified bone marrow cells.

nodes.label: Function
nodes.summary: Acts as a 'cytological patient fingerprint' by providing a quantitative summary of the bone marrow cell class probability distribution.

nodes.label: Potential Application
nodes.summary: Aims to support more efficient, consistent, and accurate diagnostic workflows in hematology, providing a foundation for AI-enabled computational pathology.

nodes.label: Machine-Learning Algorithm for Bone Marrow Cell Differential Counting
nodes.summary: Development and validation of an AI-based algorithm using a Mask R-CNN model to automate the differential counting (DC) of nucleated cells in bone marrow (BM) aspiration smears.

nodes.label: Methodology
nodes.summary: An AI model was developed using a Mask R-CNN architecture, trained on a large dataset of expert-annotated cell images from slides prepared with different staining methods.

nodes.label: AI Model Architecture
nodes.summary: A Mask Region-based Convolutional Neural Network (Mask R-CNN) was used to simultaneously detect and classify individual bone marrow cells.

nodes.label: Training and Annotation
nodes.summary: The model was trained on a large dataset of expert-annotated images. Consensus meetings were held to ensure consistent cell classification criteria among experts from different institutes.

nodes.label: Staining Methods
nodes.summary: The bone marrow slides used for training and validation were stained with either Liu’s stain or Wright–Giemsa stain.

nodes.label: Datasets Used
nodes.summary: The study utilized a large training dataset and a separate multinational, real-world dataset for clinical validation.

nodes.label: Training Dataset
nodes.summary: The AI model was trained on 542 slides containing 597,222 annotated cells. 85.1% of slides were stained with Liu’s stain and 14.9% with Wright–Giemsa stain.

nodes.label: Validation Dataset
nodes.summary: Performance was validated on a multinational real-world dataset from four centers (three in Taiwan, one in the US) comprising 200,639 cells.

nodes.label: Performance and Results
nodes.summary: The AI model achieved high accuracy in both testing and validation phases and showed a strong correlation with manual counting methods.

nodes.label: Testing Accuracy
nodes.summary: The model achieved an accuracy of 0.94 on the internal testing dataset, which contained 26,170 cells.

nodes.label: Validation Accuracy
nodes.summary: On the multinational real-world dataset, the model achieved an overall accuracy of 0.881 in classifying individual cells.

nodes.label: Cell-Specific Precision
nodes.summary: The model demonstrated high precision for key cell types: blasts (0.927), bands and polymorphonuclear neutrophils (0.955), plasma cells (0.930), and lymphocytes (0.789).

nodes.label: Correlation with Manual Counting
nodes.summary: A strong correlation (ρ > 0.8) was observed between the AI's differential counting percentages and those from manual methods for most cell categories.

nodes.label: Challenges and Background
nodes.summary: The study addresses the limitations of manual bone marrow cell counting and the difficulties in developing automated AI solutions.

nodes.label: Limitations of Manual Differential Counting
nodes.summary: Manual counting is labor-intensive, time-consuming, subject to high interobserver variation, and limited by a low number of counted cells, which can lead to sampling bias.

nodes.label: Challenges in AI Development
nodes.summary: Key challenges include collecting sufficient high-quality BM samples across diverse diseases, the technical demands of sample preparation, and the time-consuming nature of expert annotation.

nodes.label: Conclusion
nodes.summary: The study successfully developed and clinically validated an AI algorithm that can locate and classify bone marrow cells, demonstrating its potential for automating differential counting in clinical settings.
